channel.title: Google Chrome Developer Blog
channel.description: Latest blog posts from the Google Developer Blog

item.title: CSS update Media Query
item.description: Adapt your UI to the screen's refresh rate capabilities.

item.title: Improved video calling with faster AV1 encoding
item.description: Chrome 113 includes improvements to the AV1 software encoder from the Chrome Open Media team.

item.title: Blur camera background
item.description: A new origin trial from Chrome that allows web developers to control camera background blur.

item.title: New in Chrome 113
item.description: Chrome 113 is rolling out now! WebGPU is here, it allows high-performance 3D graphics and data-parallel computation on the web, devtools can now override network response headers, First Party Sets, part of the Privacy Sandbox, that allows organizations to declare related sites is starting to roll out, and there's plenty more.

item.title: Chrome 114 beta
item.description: CSS headline balancing, CHIPS, the scrollend event, and popover.

item.title: What's New in DevTools (Chrome 114)
item.description: DevTools enables Settings > Experiments > WebAssembly Debugging: Enable DWARF support by default. For more information, see Debugging WebAssembly with modern tools. This experiment lets you pause execution and debug C and C++ code in Wasm apps,

item.title: Get ready for Google I/O
item.description: Build your own agenda to prepare for Google I/O.

item.title: WebDriver BiDi: 2023 status update
item.description: This article gives an overview of what’s new in WebDriver BiDi in 2023.

item.title: 10 updates at Google I/O
item.description: Learn how we're making it easier for developers to deliver powerful experiences to their users through key updates and new launches that we shared at Google I/O 2023.

item.title: WebGPU: Unlocking modern GPU access in the browser
item.description: Learn how WebGPU unlocks the power of the GPU for faster machine learning performance and better graphics rendering.

item.title: Shared autofill across iframes: an initial proposal
item.description: Some forms have fields in iframes, which causes problems for browser autofill. With shared-autofill, the parent frame can designate the trustworthiness of cross-origin iframes, to support a better autofill experience for the user.

item.title: Find form issues with Chrome DevTools
item.description: The Chrome DevTools team is building additional new features to help find form issues and debug Autofill. These features are at an early stage of design and implementation, and we need your testing and feedback.

item.title: What’s new for web on Android 2023
item.description: Updates to tools that bring the web to Android. Privacy enhancements and better support for large screens in WebView, partial custom tabs in Custom Tabs, easier installation and integrated features for PWA, Play Store billing management for TWA and more.

item.title: What's new in CSS and UI: I/O 2023 Edition
item.description: The top 20 CSS and UI features highlighted at Google I/O 2023 that you don't want to miss.

item.title: Web SQL deprecation timeline updated
item.description: The current target version to remove Web SQL is Chromium 119.

item.title: Storage Buckets origin trial available
item.description: The Storage Standard defines an API for persistent storage and quota estimates, and the platform storage architecture. We're experimenting with an API for making persistent storage eviction under heavy memory pressure more predictable. Try the Storage Buckets API in an origin trial that runs from Chrome 115 to Chrome 118.

item.title: How the 3D model editor Blockbench uses the EyeDropper API to let users choose colors from everywhere
item.description: The EyeDropper API provides a mechanism for creating an eyedropper tool that lets users sample colors from their screens, including outside of the browser window. Learn how the 3D model editor Blockbench uses this API in their codebase. (This article

item.title: What's New with Aurora?
item.description: Learn what the Chrome Aurora team has been up to lately and their roadmap for 2023.

item.title: Introducing the popover API
item.description: Learn how to build tooltips, menus, and more with the new popover API.

item.title: DevTools Tips: Workspace
item.description: Use Workspace to save changes you make in DevTools to local source files.

item.title: Chrome disables modifying document.domain
item.description: If your website relies on setting document.domain, your action is required.

item.title: Help test bounce tracking mitigations
item.description: We plan to launch mitigations to limit tracking from a particular technique called "bounce tracking" later this year. We would like to invite developers to test this new feature with feature flags and provide feedback.

item.title: Design a superior user experience with the new Side Panel API
item.description: Introducing the new Side Panel API for Chrome extensions.

item.title: Announcing the second Compute Pressure origin trial
item.description: A new origin trial from Chrome that allows web developers to monitor compute pressure.

item.title: What's New in DevTools (Chrome 115)
item.description: The Elements panel gets a new subgrid badge for subgrid. This feature is currently experimental in Chrome Canary. To inspect and debug a nested grid that is a subgrid, and therefore inheriting the number and size of tracks from its parent, click the

item.title: New in Chrome 114
item.description: Chrome 114 is rolling out now! Chrome 114 is rolling out now! With text-wrap: balance to improve text layouts, Cookies Having Independent Partitioned State are here, the new Popover API makes popovers easier than ever, and there’s plenty more.

item.title: Chrome 115 beta
item.description: Multiple keywords for the CSS display property, WGSLLanguageFeatures for WebGPU, HTTPS upgrades, and more.

item.title: Migrate away from data URLs in SVG element
item.description: Support for data: URLs in SVG element will be removed. We recommend migration to alternatives.

item.title: What's New in WebGPU (Chrome 114)
item.description: JavaScript optimization and more.

item.title: Mutation events will be removed from Chrome
item.description: Announcing the deprecation and planned removal of mutation events, and sharing how you can migrate your code before the removal in July 2024.

item.title: Chrome for Testing: reliable downloads for browser automation
item.description: Chrome for Testing is a new Chrome flavor that specifically targets web app testing and automation use cases.

item.title: What's New in WebGPU (Chrome 115)
item.description: Supported WGSL language extensions, experimental support for Direct3D 11, and more.

item.title: What's New in DevTools (Chrome 116)
item.description: DevTools gets a number of improvements to help you identify and debug issues with missing stylesheets faster: The Network panel consistently populates the Initiator column with links to the exact line that references a stylesheet that failed to load.

item.title: Better full screen mode with the Keyboard Lock API
item.description: Use the Keyboard Lock API to capture the Escape key in full screen mode. If you've ever played a full screen web game that popped up an in-game dialog that you instinctively canceled with the Escape key, you probably found yourself kicked out of full

item.title: DevTools Tips: Local and session storage
item.description: Use Application > Local Storage and Session Storage to debug key-value pairs.

item.title: WebRTC: Legacy getStats() migration guide
item.description: Learn how to use Safari Web Inspector debugging for Chrome on iOS.

item.title: DevTools Tips: Record and replay user flows with the Recorder
item.description: Learn how to record, replay, and debug user flows with the Recorder panel in DevTools.

item.title: A case study on scroll-driven animations performance
item.description: The new API is much smoother than the classic way of implementing scroll-driven animations.

item.title: What's happening in Chrome Extensions?
item.description: An overview of the changes so far this year in Chrome Extensions, plus exciting upcoming extension features developers can look forward to.

item.title: New in Chrome 115
item.description: Use ScrollTimeline and ViewTimeline to create scroll-driven animations that enhance user experience. Fenced frames work along other Privacy Sandbox APIs to embed relevant content while preventing unnecessary context sharing. With the Topics API the browser can share information with third parties about a user's interests while preserving privacy and there’s plenty more.

item.title: Debugging websites in Chrome on iOS 16.4+
item.description: Learn how to use Safari Web Inspector debugging for Chrome on iOS.

item.title: Chrome 116 beta
item.description: CSS motion path, Back/forward cache NotRestoredReason API, Document Picture-in-Picture, and more.

item.title: What's new in Chrome 116 for Extensions
item.description: A summary of important changes in Chrome 116 for Chrome Extension developers.

item.title: DevTools Tips: Breakpoints and logpoints
item.description: Use breakpoints and logpoints to debug with ease.

item.title: One-time permissions in Chrome
item.description: "Allow this time" is a one-time option for permission grants in Chrome. It will initially be available on desktop only for geolocation, camera, and microphone.

item.title: What's New in WebGPU (Chrome 116)
item.description: WebCodecs integration, video playback improvements, and more.

item.title: Secure popup interactions with restrict-properties
item.description: Get cross-origin isolation and cross-site leaks protection while interacting with popups.

item.title: New in Chrome 116
item.description: Chrome 116 is rolling out now! Use the document picture in picture API to increase user productivity, it is now easier to debug missing stylesheets in DevTools, and there’s plenty more.

item.title: Chrome 117 beta
item.description: CSS grid subgrid, entry and exit animation support for CSS, array grouping, iterator helpers, and more.

item.title: Four new CSS features for smooth entry and exit animations
item.description: Learn about new capabilities that enable smooth transitioning of discrete animations and between the top layer

item.title: Bringing Safety check to the chrome://extensions page
item.description: Starting in Chrome 117, Chrome will proactively highlight to users when an extension they have installed is no longer in the Chrome Web Store.

item.title: What's New in DevTools (Chrome 117)
item.description: Override XHR/fetch requests and hide extension requests from the Network panel, see changes in fetch priority in the Performance panel, experience multiple UI improvements, check out new colors and experimental features, and more.

item.title: Craft your Chrome Devtools Protocol (CDP) commands efficiently with the new command editor
item.description: To make it easier to type Chrome Devtools Protocol (CDP) commands, DevTools introduced a new user-friendly editor so that you don't have to use JSON.

item.title: What's new in Lighthouse 11
item.description: Lighthouse 11 is here with new accessibility changes and audit updates

item.title: Introducing the scheduler.yield origin trial
item.description: `scheduler.yield` is a proposed new addition to the scheduler API currently in origin trial, and is a novel approach to breaking up tasks for more responsive user experiences. Understand the benefits of this proposed addition to the scheduling API, and sign up for the origin trial to help us gain insights and feedback.

item.title: Faster Chrome releases (round two!)
item.description: From Chrome 119 we will shorten the time between the branch for a release and release to stable.

item.title: Astro View Transitions
item.description: Highlight how the Astro community embraced View Transitions when Chrome was shaping up the API and the journey towards landing first-class support for it in Astro + persistent islands.

item.title: DevTools Tips: Snippets and live expressions
item.description: Use Snippets to run code you frequently use and live expressions to watch values in real time.

item.title: Google Summer of Code and Chrome Extensions
item.description: Experience and advice on participating in Google Summer of Code.

item.title: What's New in WebGPU (Chrome 117)
item.description: Unset vertex buffer and bind group, make lost devices appear to function, and more.

item.title: New in Chrome 117
item.description: Chrome 117 is rolling out now! With three new CSS features that make it easy to add smooth entry and exit animations, array grouping to compute higher order datasets, devtools makes local overrides easier and there’s plenty more.

item.title: Chrome 118 beta
item.description: Scoped styles for CSS, additional media features, keyboard-focusable scroll containers, and more.

item.title: What's New in DevTools (Chrome 118)
item.description: New section for custom properties in Elements > Styles, more local overrides improvements, enhanced search, streamlined workspace in Sources, and more.

item.title: From WebGL to WebGPU
item.description: Learn some tips for WebGL developers who are migrating to WebGPU.

item.title: We are Chrome for Developers
item.description: Celebrating Chrome's 15th anniversary and our role as a trusted, helpful partner to developers.

item.title: Seamless navigation made possible with view transitions
item.description: An in-depth walkthrough of how and why CyberAgent, RedBus, Nykaa, and PolicyBazaar implemented view transitions.

item.title: DevTools Tips: Debugging Chrome extensions
item.description: Learn how to use DevTools to debug Chrome extensions.

item.title: What's New in WebGPU (Chrome 118)
item.description: Extended source support for copyExternalImageToTexture, experimental support for read-write and read-only storage texture, and more.

item.title: Chrome now supports passkeys on iCloud Keychain on macOS
item.description: Chrome on macOS starts supporting passkeys on iCloud Keychain. This lets users create passkeys on iCloud Keychain and synchronize them across Apple devices.

item.title: Chrome 119 beta
item.description: Chrome 119 beta brings you CSS relative color syntax, new pseudo-classes, and much more.

item.title: New origin trial for fullscreen popup windows
item.description: There's now a new origin trial available for opening popup windows in fullscreen mode with just one step.

item.title: API Improvements for working with files in the browser
item.description: Support for multiple readers and writers for FileSystemSyncAccessHandle and exclusive writer for FileSystemWritableFileStream. The origin private file system (sometimes also referred to as the bucket file system) allows developers to access files

item.title: What's New in DevTools (Chrome 119)
item.description: Improved @property section in Styles, updated devices list, enhanced pretty-printing in Sources and autocompletion in the Console.

item.title: New in Chrome 118
item.description: Chrome 118 is rolling out now! Declare specific styles within a component with the @scope css rule. Use new media feature: prefers-reduced-transparency. DevTools has improvements in the Sources panel and there's plenty more.

item.title: CSS relative color syntax
item.description: Create new colors based on another color's channels and values.

item.title: Serial over Bluetooth on the web
item.description: The Web Serial API added support for Bluetooth RFCOMM services.

item.title: Sanitizer API deprecation
item.description: The current Sanitizer API implementation is deprecated from Chrome 119 to catch up with future specification updates.

item.title: Chromium issue tracker migration
item.description: Chromium issue tracking is migrating to a tool powered by the Google Issue tracker in January 2024.

item.title: What's happening in Chrome Extensions?
item.description: An overview of the recent changes in Chrome Extensions, plus exciting upcoming extension features developers can look forward to.

item.title: CSS text-wrap: pretty
item.description: Opt-in optimized text wrapping, for beauty over speed.

item.title: Select element: now with horizontal rules
item.description: Learn how expanded select element capabilities enable visual horizontal breaks for better grouping.

item.title: What's New in WebGPU (Chrome 119)
item.description: Filterable 32-bit float textures, unorm10-10-10-2 vertex format, rgb10a2uint texture format, and more.

item.title: CSS prefers-reduced-transparency
item.description: Optimize and adjust for users who prefer an opaque UI.

item.title: New in Chrome 119
item.description: Chrome 119 is rolling out now! With an update to the expiration date upper limit for cookies already in storage. CSS has new pseudo classes, relative color syntax, Fenced Frames improvements like ad size macros, and there’s plenty more.

item.title: WebAssembly Garbage Collection (WasmGC) now enabled by default in Chrome
item.description: There are two types of programming languages: garbage-collected programming languages and programming languages that require manual memory management. This article explains how thanks to WebAssembly Garbage Collection, short WasmGC, garbage-collected languages can be ported to WebAssembly.

item.title: Chrome 120 beta
item.description: CSS masking, relaxed rules for CSS nesting, create accordion patterns with the element, the enterpictureinpicture action for the Media Session API.

item.title: What's new in Chrome 120 for Extensions
item.description: A summary of important changes in Chrome 120 for Chrome Extension developers.

item.title: A change to the default durability mode in IndexedDB
item.description: The durability mode in IndexedDB is changing from strict to relaxed from Chrome 121.

item.title: What's new in DevTools (Chrome 120)
item.description: Third-party cookie phaseout issues reported in the Issues panel, Privacy Sandbox Analysis Tool for cookies, effective Content Security Policy in the Applications panel, improved animations debugging, enhanced ignore listing, and more.

item.title: Capturing the WebGPU ecosystem
item.description: Learn about how the WebGPU ecosystem extends beyond the JavaScript, C++, and Rust realms.

item.title: What’s new in the Angular NgOptimizedImage directive
item.description: Learn about the new features included in the Angular NgOptimizedImage directive that further improve image performance in Angular apps.

item.title: Improving content filtering in Manifest V3
item.description: Over the past year, we have been actively involved in discussions with the vendors behind several content blocking extensions around ways to improve the MV3 extensions platform. Based on these discussions, many of which took place in the

item.title: Automatic picture-in-picture for web apps
item.description: Chrome allows video conferencing web apps to automatically enter picture-in-picture.

item.title: Resuming the transition to Manifest V3
item.description: In December of last year, we paused the planned deprecation of Manifest V2 in order to address developer feedback and deliver better solutions to migration issues. As a result of this feedback, we’ve made a number of changes to Manifest V3 to close

item.title: Introducing four new international features in CSS
item.description: Chrome is adding four new international CSS features.

item.title: New in Chrome 120
item.description: Chrome 120 is rolling out now! With the CloseWatcher API to enable a consistent experience when handling close requests, an straightforward implementation of an accordion pattern using the details element, permission policy violation reports are now available and there's plenty more.

item.title: Private Network Access Permission prompt origin trial: A path to migrate websites with HTTPS
item.description: Google Chrome is deprecating access to private network endpoints from non-secure public websites as part of the Private Network Access (PNA) specification.

item.title: DevTools Tips: Debugging bfcache
item.description: Learn how to debug bfcache and make your page load instantly.

item.title: DevTools Tips: What is DOM? HTML versus DOM
item.description: Learn how to debug the DOM with DevTools.

item.title: Revisiting Chrome's installability criteria
item.description: In the coming months Chrome will be running experiments with the goal of simplifying the app install criteria, to improve developer and user experience. This post shares the changes you can expect, and the reasons we are running these experiments.

item.title: How Chrome DevTools helps to defend against self-XSS attacks
item.description: Learn how Chrome DevTools mitigates self-XSS attacks by blocking code pasting for inexperienced users of DevTools.

item.title: Chrome 121 beta
item.description: CSS Scrollbars, the Storage Buckets API, the Speculation Rules API, and more.

item.title: CSS Wrapped: 2023!
item.description: 2023 was a huge year for CSS! Learn about what landed in Chrome and across the web platform this year.

item.title: What's New in WebGPU (Chrome 120)
item.description: Support for 16-bit floating-point values in WGSL, limits increase, depth-stencil state changes, adapter information updates, and more.

item.title: What's new in DevTools (Chrome 121)
item.description: @font-palette-values support in Elements, improved source map support, enhanced Performance > Interactions track, and more.

item.title: Chrome enables desktop mode by default on premium tablets
item.description: Chrome has adapted to the Android tablet ecosystem by enabling desktop mode by default on premium tablets.

item.title: Harness the power of WebDriver BiDi: Chrome and Firefox automation with Puppeteer
item.description: Puppeteer now talks to Firefox! 🎉 But wait, didn't it already? 🤔 Let's dive into WebDriver BiDi, the new protocol in Puppeteer and discover what this exciting development means for the Firefox automation workflow.

item.title: DevTools Tips: Debugging fetch priority
item.description: Learn how to debug fetch priority.

item.title: DevTools Tips: Authoring colors
item.description: Learn how to author colors in a few clicks.

item.title: Persistent permissions for the File System Access API
item.description: This post explains how persistent permissions for the File System Access API can be managed. It also provides a quick recap of the current state of the problem and the challenges that are being solved.

item.title: CSS vertical writing mode for form control elements
item.description: Chrome adds another new international CSS feature.

item.title: Supercharge Web AI model testing: WebGPU, WebGL, and Headless Chrome
item.description: Discover our solutions for how to consistently automate browser testing and improve application performance.

item.title: Test Web Bluetooth with Puppeteer
item.description: Use Puppeteer to test features that use the Web Bluetooth API in Chrome.

item.title: Safely accessing the DOM with Angular SSR
item.description: Learn how to safely use the DOM together with SSR in Angular

item.title: What's New in WebGPU (Chrome 121)
item.description: Support WebGPU on Android, use of DXC for shader compilation, timestamp queries in compute and render passes, default entry points to shader modules, support display-p3 as GPUExternalTexture color space, memory heaps info, and more.

item.title: What's happening in Chrome Extensions?
item.description: An overview of the recent changes in Chrome Extensions, plus exciting upcoming extension features developers can look forward to.

item.title: New in Chrome 121
item.description: Chrome 121 is rolling out now! With CSS updates, improvements to the Speculation Rules API, an origin trial for Element Capture API and there's plenty more. Adriana Jara has all the details about what's new for developers in Chrome 121.

item.title: Chrome 122 beta
item.description: Chrome 122 beta brings you Iterator helpers, set methods, the Storage Buckets API, read unsanitized HTML in the Async Clipboard API, and more.

item.title: The deprecation trial for SharedArrayBuffer on desktop Chrome is extended to Chrome 124
item.description: The deprecation trial for SharedArrayBuffer without cross-origin isolation on Chrome desktop is extended until Chrome 124.

item.title: Join Privacy Sandbox Office Hours #12: Learn about Chrome-facilitated testing
item.description: Join the 12th edition of Privacy Sandbox office hours dedicated to Chrome-facilitated testing, where the Privacy Sandbox team will provide some Privacy Sandbox tester updates and answer your questions with product and technical leads.

item.title: DevTools Tips: Debugging speculative navigations for faster page loads
item.description: Make web browsing faster with speculative loads and learn how to debug them.

item.title: Introducing a new way to build custom web editing experiences using the EditContext API
item.description: EditContext is a new API launching in Chrome and Edge that helps developers to build advanced text editing features in the browser. Learn more about it in this post!

item.title: What's new in DevTools (Chrome 122)
item.description: Third-party cookies phaseout warnings in the Network and Application panels, enhanced debugging in the Network panel, breadcrumbs in the Performance panel, and more.

item.title: Chromium Issue Tracker migration beginning Feb 2, 2024 at 5pm PST
item.description: The Chromium Issue Tracker migration begins today.

item.title: Chromium Issue Tracker migration is complete
item.description: Chromium issue tracking is now migrated.

item.title: What's New in WebGPU (Chrome 122)
item.description: Compatibility mode in development, increase maxVertexAttributes limit, and Dawn updates.

item.title: A 400% faster Performance panel through perf-ception
item.description: The Performance panel in DevTools is a powerful tool to diagnose, debug and fix performance issues of web apps. On this occasion, we will walk you through how we used the Performance panel in DevTools to improve the performance of the Performance panel itself, and how we achieved a very significant improvement.

item.title: Changes to CSS ::backdrop inheritance
item.description: As of Chrome 122 the `::backdrop` element inherits properties from its originating element.

item.title: Announcing Chrome for Developers in China
item.description: We are publishing our sites on a .cn domain to make them easier to access in China.

item.title: New in Chrome 122
item.description: Chrome 122 is rolling out now! With the new Storage Buckets API, DevTools Performance panel updates, unsanitized option to read HTML with the Async Clipboard API and there's plenty more. Adriana Jara has all the details about what's new for developers in Chrome 122.

item.title: Chrome 123 beta
item.description: The CSS light-dark() color function, align-content for blocks, the field-sizing property, and the pagereveal event.

item.title: Support for align-content in block and table layouts
item.description: From Chrome 123 use align-content to align items without creating a flex or grid container.

item.title: Changes to BFCache behavior with extension message ports
item.description: We are making changes to Chrome BFCache which potentially impact extensions using message ports.

item.title: A Next.js package for managing third-party libraries
item.description: Learn how to use the @next/third-parties library to optimize loading of popular third-party resources

item.title: What's new in DevTools (Chrome 123)
item.description: An Easter egg, focused page emulation in Elements > Styles, new Lighthouse audit, and more.

item.title: Chrome Extensions: eyeo's journey to testing service worker suspension
item.description: In this post, the eyeo team shares their journey into the problem of testing extension service workers. In particular, how to to make sure that their Chrome Extensions works correctly when a service worker gets suspended.

item.title: Improvements to the Speculation Rules API
item.description: Details of the latest updates to the Speculation Rules API including document rules, eagerness setting, limits, and speculation rules support on platforms.

item.title: Download old Headless Chrome as chrome-headless-shell
item.description: You can now download the old Headless Chrome as a standalone binary for every user-facing Chrome release.

item.title: Supercharge compression efficiency with shared dictionaries
item.description: Compression on the web is getting a big boost from shared dictionary compression. Learn what they are, how they work, and how they could substantially reduce load times even further than standard compression for both static and dynamic resources on the web.

item.title: What's New in WebGPU (Chrome 123)
item.description: DP4a built-in functions support, unrestricted pointer parameters, syntax sugar for dereferencing composites in WGSL, and more.

item.title: Hide extension requests plus more Network panel improvements
item.description: Explore the latest improvements in Chrome DevTools Network panel, designed to simplify your web debugging experience.

item.title: Performance tooling in 2024 and beyond
item.description: Learn about the Chrome team's plans to improve the Performance panel of DevTools.

item.title: Use the Service Worker Static Routing API to bypass the service worker for specific paths
item.description: Find out how to use this new API, available from Chrome 123.

item.title: Private Network Access: Extended protection for web workers and navigation fetches
item.description: Learn about Private Network Access's key security mechanisms for web workers, navigation fetches, and upcoming protections. This document also covers what website owners should do if they utilize private networks.

item.title: New in Chrome 123
item.description: Chrome 123 is rolling out now! With the new light-dark function, Long Animation Frames API, Service Worker Static Routing API and there's plenty more. Adriana Jara has all the details about what's new for developers in Chrome 123.

item.title: Chrome 124 beta
item.description: The writingsuggestions HTML attribute, the WebSocketStream API, priority HTTP request header, and more.

item.title: Keyboard focusable scrollers
item.description: A change is rolling out to make scrollers without tabindex value set and with no focusable children keyboard focusable.

item.title: The fetchLater API Origin Trial
item.description: Learn about the fetchLater API—now in an Origin Trial—a new API for requesting a deferred fetch that will complete even if the page is closed.

item.title: WebAssembly JavaScript Promise Integration (JSPI) enters origin trial
item.description: JavaScript Promise Integration (JSPI) is an API that allows synchronous sequential code compiled to WebAssembly to access asynchronous Web APIs.

item.title: Goodbye JS Profiler, profiling CPU with the Performance panel
item.description: Learn the path forward in profiling CPU performance, understand why and how we deprecate the JavaScript profiler.

item.title: What's new in DevTools, Chrome 124
item.description: Scroll-driven animations support, new Autofill panel, new options for WebRTC in network throttling, and more.

item.title: Navigation types now available in CrUX
item.description: Learn about the new navigation_types metric in the Chrome User Experience Report (CrUX) and how it can be used to explain and optimize your web performance metrics.

item.title: What's New in WebGPU (Chrome 124)
item.description: Read-only and read-write storage textures, service workers and shared workers support, new adapter information attributes, and bug fixes.

item.title: Version rollbacks in the Chrome Web Store Developer Dashboard
item.description: This week we're excited to launch a new feature that lets developers roll back their extensions to the previous published version in the Chrome Web Store. Our goal is to give developers increased peace-of-mind when publishing updates, especially with

item.title: Fun & Powerful: Intro to Chrome DevTools
item.description: Discover how DevTools can improve your web application development.

item.title: Origin trial for Foldable APIs
item.description: The Foldable APIs are two APIs in Chrome that are designed to help developers target foldable devices.

item.title: Access to MIDI devices now requires user permission
item.description: Chrome now gates the entire Web MIDI API behind a permission prompt.

item.title: What's happening in Chrome Extensions?
item.description: An overview of the recent changes in Chrome Extensions, plus exciting upcoming extension features developers can look forward to.

item.title: New in Chrome 124
item.description: Chrome 124 is rolling out now! There are two new APIs that allow the declarative shadow DOM to be used from JavaScript. You can use streams in Web Sockets. View Transitions get a little better. And there's plenty more. Pete LePage has all the details about what's new for developers in Chrome 124.

item.title: Chrome 125 beta
item.description: CSS Anchor Positioning, CSS stepped functions, the Compute Pressure API, and more.

item.title: The Private Network Access (PNA) for non-secure contexts deprecation trial is ending—implement the PNA permission prompt
item.description: To access private network devices from a website that cannot be converted to HTTPS, you must use permission prompts to relax mixed content checks.

item.title: An alternative proposal for CSS masonry
item.description: A proposal to define masonry and grid in different specifications.

item.title: Introducing "Unleash the power of Scroll-Driven Animations"
item.description: A 10-part video course to learn all about scroll-driven animations

item.title: What's New in WebGPU (Chrome 125)
item.description: Subgroups in development and render to slice of 3D texture.

item.title: Why do CSS and UI capabilities matter for your ecommerce site?
item.description: Learn how ecommerce sites benefit from implementing the latest CSS and UI features—View Transitions, Scroll-driven animations, Popover API, and more.

item.title: What's new in DevTools, Chrome 125
item.description: Error causes in the Console, CSS selector statistics in Performance, Early Hints headers in Network, and more.

item.title: Tools from Chrome for frictionless, automated testing
item.description: A brief overview of Puppeteer, Chrome Headless and Chrome for Testing and other resources from the Chrome Tooling team.

item.title: Implement testing in your enterprise with Chrome
item.description: Learn how to overcome challenges with testing in enterprise environments

item.title: Introducing the CSS anchor positioning API
item.description: Position elements relative to each other using the new anchor positioning API.

item.title: 10 updates from Google I/O 2024: Unlocking the power of AI for every web developer
item.description: Discover exciting features from the Google I/O Developer Keynote and sessions.

item.title: DevTools Tips: Override and mock network responses
item.description: Learn how you can override and mock network responses with DevTools.

item.title: New in Chrome 125
item.description: Chrome 125 is rolling out now! With the CSS Anchor Positioning API, the Compute Pressure API, an expansion to the Storage Access API, and plenty more. Adriana Jara has all the details about what's new for developers in Chrome 125.

item.title: Introducing UIA support on Windows
item.description: From Chrome 126 the Windows UI Automation framework is supported.

item.title: SVG support for the Async Clipboard API
item.description: The Async Clipboard API can now deal with SVG images.

item.title: What's new in view transitions? (Google I/O 2024 update)
item.description: Announcing cross-document view transitions for MPA, selective view transitions with active types, and sharing animation styles with view-transition-class.

item.title: I/O 2024 Web AI wrap up: New models, tools, and APIs for your next web app
item.description: Read a wrap up from Web AI at I/O 2024. Learn about the new models, tools, and APIs for your next web app.

item.title: Chrome 126 beta
item.description: Chrome 126 Beta includes cross-document view transitions, along with the Gamepad API trigger-rumble extension, and other features.

item.title: What's new in JavaScript Frameworks (May 2024)
item.description: This document provides brief highlights of recent happenings in the JavaScript frameworks ecosystem.

item.title: WebAssembly and WebGPU enhancements for faster Web AI, part 1
item.description: Part 1/2. Learn how WebAssembly and WebGPU enhancements improve machine learning performance on the web.

item.title: WebAssembly and WebGPU enhancements for faster Web AI, part 2
item.description: Part 2/2. Learn how WebAssembly and WebGPU enhancements improve machine learning performance on the web.
